newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS - Australia tin output seen same after ATP exit.
newsitem.headline: RTRS - Australia tin output seen same after ATP exit.

text.p: Australian tin production will not be affected by the government's decision to withdraw from the Association of Tin Producing Countries (ATPC), tin mining companies said on Thursday.

The 13 year old association had become no more than a discussion forum in recent years with no regulatory powers to control production and exports, they said. The Australian government plans to withdraw from the ATPC from December 10.
Peter Robinson, director of operations for RGC said the association was "already dead in all but name," and had long outlived its usefulness.
Renison expects to produce about 10,000 tonnes of tin from its Renison Bell mine in Tasmania in 1996.
Another 10,000 tonnes will be produced from Renison's 75 pct owned Pt Koba mine in Indonesia.

Norminco Ltd, which plans to export up to 800 tonnes of tin concentrates to Malaysia in 1996, also sees little impact from the withdrawal. "Our view is that it is not a critical blow," said company secretary George Strickland.
Thailand recently signalled its intention to withdraw from the ATPC and other countries may follow. Robinson said he would not be surprised if Indonesia was to quit at some stage.
